articles.headline: How a Relief Fund for Restaurants Picked Winners and Losers
articles.snippet: First, the Restaurant Revitalization Fund was supposed to promote equity. Then the grants were meant to be first come first served. Both ways had problems.
articles.abstract: First, the Restaurant Revitalization Fund was supposed to promote equity. Then the grants were meant to be first come first served. Both ways had problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Congress created a grant program early this year to help battered bars and restaurants survive the pandemic, one thing was immediately clear: The money would not be enough. The Restaurant Revitalization Fund contained $28.6 billion, far below the $100 billion that industry groups estimated was needed.

articles.headline: Democrats Say They Are Serious About State Elections. But Are They Too Late?
articles.snippet: State-level races are becoming a central focus of American politics as the lasting effects of new congressional maps and election laws raise the stakes.
articles.abstract: State-level races are becoming a central focus of American politics as the lasting effects of new congressional maps and election laws raise the stakes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Late on Nov. 8, 2016, the mood inside President Barack Obama’s West Wing turned grim. Hillary Clinton was coming up short. The realization was growing that Donald J. Trump would be elected president.

articles.headline: C.D.C. Faces Pressure to Change Isolation Guidelines for Sick Workers
articles.snippet: Facing staffing shortages, companies are weighing conflicting guidance on when employees who have tested positive for the coronavirus can safely return to work.
articles.abstract: Facing staffing shortages, companies are weighing conflicting guidance on when employees who have tested positive for the coronavirus can safely return to work.
articles.lead_paragraph: Barbara Sibley’s four New York restaurants had already weathered the city’s initial Covid-19 wave, the prevaccine surge last winter and this summer’s Delta spike when last weekend it finally happened: Fearing an outbreak and struggling with staffing after one of her workers got sick with Covid, she temporarily shut down one of her locations.
articles.byline: By Lauren Hirsch and Emma Goldberg

articles.headline: The Students Returned, but the Fallout From a Long Disruption Remained
articles.snippet: “They’re like, ‘The world’s out of control, why should I be in control?’” the principal of Liberty High School in Bethlehem, Pa., said of some of his struggling students.
articles.abstract: “They’re like, ‘The world’s out of control, why should I be in control?’” the principal of Liberty High School in Bethlehem, Pa., said of some of his struggling students.
articles.lead_paragraph: BETHLEHEM, Pa. — Three hours into a recent Monday morning, blood had already been spilled in a hallway at Liberty High School. With his walkie-talkie in hand, the principal, Harrison Bailey III, called on the custodial staff to clean up the remnants of a brawl while hurrying to the cafeteria in hopes of staving off another.

articles.headline: As Omicron Overshadows Christmas, Thousands of Flights Are Canceled
articles.snippet: Travelers had hoped this holiday season would represent a return to relative normalcy. Instead, pilots are out and delays are piling up.
articles.abstract: Travelers had hoped this holiday season would represent a return to relative normalcy. Instead, pilots are out and delays are piling up.
articles.lead_paragraph: Thousands of frustrated travelers hoping to fly to Christmas celebrations faced a wave of last-minute cancellations, as a spike in coronavirus cases sidelined airline workers who had contracted the virus or had been exposed to the fast-spreading Omicron variant.
articles.byline: By Karen Weise and Glenn Thrush

articles.headline: As Omicron Spreads and Cases Soar, the Unvaccinated Remain Defiant
articles.snippet: To some who are steadfastly opposed to the shot, the evasiveness of the coronavirus has only reaffirmed their stance.
articles.abstract: To some who are steadfastly opposed to the shot, the evasiveness of the coronavirus has only reaffirmed their stance.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — As a fast-spreading new strain of the coronavirus swarms across the country, hospitals in Ohio running low on beds and staff recently took out a full-page newspaper advertisement pleading with unvaccinated Americans to finally get the shot. It read, simply: “Help.”
articles.byline: By Jack Healy, Noah Weiland and Richard Fausset

articles.headline: As Prices Rise, Biden Turns to Antitrust Enforcers
articles.snippet: A wide-ranging presidential order helped block a railroad merger and tackle supply-chain problems, and it is planting the seeds for bigger actions.
articles.abstract: A wide-ranging presidential order helped block a railroad merger and tackle supply-chain problems, and it is planting the seeds for bigger actions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As rising inflation threatens his presidency, President Biden is turning to the federal government’s antitrust authorities to try to tame red-hot price increases that his administration believes are partly driven by a lack of corporate competition.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: Desmond Tutu, Whose Voice Helped Slay Apartheid, Dies at 90
articles.snippet: The archbishop, a powerful force for nonviolence in South Africa’s anti-apartheid movement, was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1984.
articles.abstract: The archbishop, a powerful force for nonviolence in South Africa’s anti-apartheid movement, was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1984.
articles.lead_paragraph: Desmond M. Tutu, the cleric who used his pulpit and spirited oratory to help bring down apartheid in South Africa and then became the leading advocate of peaceful reconciliation under Black majority rule, died on Sunday in Cape Town. He was 90.

articles.headline: First They Fought About Masks. Then Over the Soul of the City.
articles.snippet: In Enid, Okla., pandemic politics prompted a fundamental question: What does it mean to be an American? Whose version of the country will prevail?
articles.abstract: In Enid, Okla., pandemic politics prompted a fundamental question: What does it mean to be an American? Whose version of the country will prevail?
articles.lead_paragraph: ENID, Okla. — On a hot night in July, the first summer of the pandemic, Jonathan Waddell, a city commissioner in Enid, Okla., sat staring out at a rowdy audience dressed in red. They were in the third hour of public comments on a proposed mask mandate, and Mr. Waddell, a retired Air Force sergeant who supported it, was feeling increasingly uncomfortable.

articles.headline: ‘Magic’ Weight-Loss Pills and Covid Cures: Dr. Oz Under the Microscope
articles.snippet: The celebrity physician, a candidate in Pennsylvania’s Republican primary for Senate, has a long history of dispensing dubious medical advice on his daytime show and on Fox News.
articles.abstract: The celebrity physician, a candidate in Pennsylvania’s Republican primary for Senate, has a long history of dispensing dubious medical advice on his daytime show and on Fox News.
articles.lead_paragraph: A wealth of evidence now shows that the malaria drugs hydroxychloroquine and chloroquine were not effective at treating Covid-19 and carried potential risks.

articles.headline: Training Civilians, Ukraine Nurtures a Resistance in Waiting
articles.snippet: Eastern European nations have drawn a lesson from America’s wars of the last decades: Insurgency works. Ukraine’s training of volunteers has become a factor in the standoff with Russia.
articles.abstract: Eastern European nations have drawn a lesson from America’s wars of the last decades: Insurgency works. Ukraine’s training of volunteers has become a factor in the standoff with Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — In a pine forest not far from Ukraine’s capital, a mock battle raged. Commanders barked orders. Figures in camouflage huddled behind trees. A soldier fell to the ground, yelling for help.

articles.headline: Hollywood Tests the Limit of Marquee Names a Single Film Can Hold
articles.snippet: Boldface names have always mattered at the movies, but a number of recent casts have been full of them. That hasn’t always helped at the box office.
articles.abstract: Boldface names have always mattered at the movies, but a number of recent casts have been full of them. That hasn’t always helped at the box office.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — On Friday, Netflix began streaming “Don’t Look Up,” a big-budget satire starring Leonardo DiCaprio, Jennifer Lawrence, Tyler Perry, Ariana Grande, Jonah Hill, Meryl Streep, Cate Blanchett and Timothée Chalamet.

articles.headline: How Paid Experts Help Exonerate Police After Deaths in Custody
articles.snippet: Inside the self-reinforcing ecosystem of people who advise, train and defend officers. Many accuse them of slanting science and perpetuating aggressive tactics.
articles.abstract: Inside the self-reinforcing ecosystem of people who advise, train and defend officers. Many accuse them of slanting science and perpetuating aggressive tactics.
articles.lead_paragraph: When lawyers were preparing to defend against a lawsuit over a death in police custody in Fresno, Calif., they knew whom to call.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Valentino-DeVries, Mike McIntire, Rebecca R. Ruiz, Julie Tate and Michael H. Keller

articles.headline: The Companies Benefiting From Fragmenting Internet Privacy Rules
articles.snippet: Companies have sprouted up to help others navigate the varied laws around the world governing websites.
articles.abstract: Companies have sprouted up to help others navigate the varied laws around the world governing websites.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANDY SPRINGS, Ga. — In 2018, California lawmakers mandated that consumers be able to request their personal data from companies through a toll-free number. And then a group of lawyers, engineers and salespeople for a company in Atlanta got to work.

articles.headline: Record Beef Prices, but Ranchers Aren’t Cashing In
articles.snippet: “You’re feeding America and going broke doing it”: After years of consolidation, four companies dominate the meatpacking industry, while many ranchers are barely hanging on.
articles.abstract: “You’re feeding America and going broke doing it”: After years of consolidation, four companies dominate the meatpacking industry, while many ranchers are barely hanging on.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHEPHERD, Montana — Judging from the prices at supermarkets and restaurants, this would appear to be a lucrative moment for cattle ranchers like Steve Charter.
articles.byline: By Peter S. Goodman and Erin Schaff

articles.headline: As Other Arab States Falter, Saudi Arabia Seeks to Become a Cultural Hub
articles.snippet: While conflicts and crises have battered Arab cultural capitals, Saudi Arabia is hosting film festivals and bankrolling new movies.
articles.abstract: While conflicts and crises have battered Arab cultural capitals, Saudi Arabia is hosting film festivals and bankrolling new movies.
articles.lead_paragraph: JEDDAH, Saudi Arabia — A pregnant Saudi woman, far from home, finds herself stalked by inner and outer demons. A wannabe Saudi vlogger and his friends, menaced by the internet’s insatiable appetite for content and more mysterious dangers, try to escape a dark forest. At a wedding, the mother of the bride panics when her daughter disappears with all of their guests waiting downstairs.
articles.byline: By Vivian Yee and Ben Hubbard
